para.paratext: The privilege against self-incrimination is a personal privilege that can be claimed or waived only by the person owning the privilege. The privilege is not waived merely because the witness testified to the same matter at a previous trial.[1] The privilege cannot be claimed by a corporation.[2] In denying the privilege to a labor union, an unincorporated association, Justice Murphy wrote: “The constitutional privilege against self-incrimination is essentially a personal one, applying only to natural individuals.”[3] Thus, the records of a corporation or association would be subject to discovery regardless of whether they might be incriminating and the officers in charge could not refuse to produce the records by claiming that they would incriminate them personally, because the records do not belong to the officers. Georgia courts follow the same rule. In Jacobs v. State,[4] the Georgia Court of Appeals cited United States Supreme Court precedent to clarify that “corporate books and records cannot be insulated from reasonable demands by governmental authorities by a claim of personal privilege.” Likewise, “[a] corporate officer may not withhold testimony or documents on the ground that the corporation would be incriminated …. Nor may the custodian of corporate books or records withhold them on the ground that he personally might be incriminated by their production.”[5]
Robinson v. State, 216 Ga. App. 816, 456 S.E.2d 68 (1995).

Classic Art Corp. v. State, 245 Ga. 448, 265 S.E.2d 577 (1980) (holding that a corporation cannot claim the privilege against self-incrimination under the Fifth Amendment or O.C.G.A. § 24-9-20 [§ 24-5-506 eff. Jan. 1, 2013]).

U.S. v. White, 322 U.S. 694, 64 S. Ct. 1248, 88 L. Ed. 1542, 152 A.L.R. 1202 (1944). U.S. v. Rylander, 460 U.S. 752, 103 S. Ct. 1548, 75 L. Ed. 2d 521 (1983), involved an IRS summons against the president of a corporation. Requiring him to produce evidence that he did not possess, the records did not violate his privilege.
Jacobs v. State, 157 Ga. App. 466, 468, 278 S.E.2d 21 (1981).
Jacobs v. State, 157 Ga. App. 466, 468, 278 S.E.2d 21 (1981) (internal cite omitted).
